title: Roadmap (Colab-Optimized, Technology Modules Only)
text:
Global conventions (apply to every module)

Cell ID: cell <major.minor>: <technology>: <purpose>
Colab setup: Every module begins with its own pip cell & imports (so modules can be moved/omitted without breakage).
Artifacts: Each module writes to outputs/<tech>/‚Ä¶ and never reads from future modules.
Plots: Use matplotlib only (reliable on Colab). If a plot needs later tech, move the entire visualization to that later module.
Runtime discipline: Seed set in each module; batch sizes capped; small models selected; .cache used by ü§ó to reduce re-downloads.




Why first: Fast, no heavy deps. Establishes readability, frequency, and basic lexical dispersion.

Installs: cell 1.1: textstat|wordfreq: install
%pip install -q textstat wordfreq regex
Imports & checks: cell 1.2: textstat|wordfreq: imports & sanity checks
Features: Readability indices, type‚Äìtoken ratio (TTR), Zipf frequency stats, punctuation/length distributions. cell 1.3: textstat: readability metrics cell 1.4: wordfreq: Zipf frequency features cell 1.5: lexicons: function-word profile & TTR
Visuals (local): Histograms/boxplots for sentence length, Zipf freq; radar for function words (matplotlib). cell 1.6: textstat|wordfreq: visuals ‚Äî baseline distributions
Output: outputs/textstat_lex/lexical_features.parquet





Why now: Light dependency; supports function-word baselines and burstiness.

title: Roadmap (Colab-Optimized, Technology Modules Only)
text:
Human-authored (positive ‚Äúhuman‚Äù class)

Wikipedia (Good/Featured articles): High-quality human prose; scrape via Hugging Face datasets: wikipedia (filter by quality tags if available) or fetch curated lists.
Project Gutenberg (non-fiction essays, public domain): Varied style; lightweight text.
AG News (train split): Human news headlines + descriptions (short, focused; good for sanity checks).
WMT News Crawl (year subset): Human news sentences; pick a small year slice (e.g., 2019 EN).

title: Roadmap (Colab-Optimized, Technology Modules Only)
text:
Synthetic (positive ‚Äúsynthetic‚Äù class)

HC3 (Hello-SimpleAI/HC3): Human vs.¬†ChatGPT Q&A pairs across domains; widely used baseline for H/S detection.
Human-LLM pairs on Hugging Face (small, curated sets; e.g., ‚Äúllm-detect-ai-text‚Äù style datasets) ‚Äî sample lightly to avoid domain bias.
Self-generated synthetic (fallback): Use distilgpt2 to create synthetic paraphrases of human windows (clearly marked as synthetic for calibration only). This keeps everything open & reproducible when third-party corpora are constrained.

title: Roadmap (Colab-Optimized, Technology Modules Only)
text:
Hybrid post-edit (for S‚ÜíH / H‚ÜíS cues)

Create controlled hybrids (recommended, reproducible):

H‚ÜíS: Take human windows ‚Üí paraphrase with distilgpt2 (temperature ~0.7) ‚Üí retain semantics, reduce idioms.
S‚ÜíH: Take synthetic windows ‚Üí light human edits (typos/idioms/clarifications) applied by your team.
These give you labeled seams to tune change-point thresholds without external dependencies.



Calibration plan: Start with unsupervised thresholds ‚Üí evaluate on the above small references ‚Üí optionally fit isotonic on a tiny validation split. Always keep an Uncertain band to reflect overlap.

text:

From the code reviewer: Got the updated Module 5 bundle‚Äînice work. I pulled the new artifacts and metadata and here‚Äôs a tight review you can drop into the notes.

title: Verdict
text:
What looks solid

Model + device pinned: sentence-transformers/all-MiniLM-L6-v2, dim=384, device=CPU, embeddings normalized (cosine in [0,1]).
Window policy matches M2: from_module_2_spans/full_containment with windows_total=349, windows_with_lt2_sentences=0 (good guard).
Clear coherence definition: cosine_mean_offdiag (mean of off-diagonal sentence-pair similarities).
Artifacts produced:

semantic_metrics.parquet
coherence_doc.parquet
coherence_windows.parquet
Plots: global doc violin, per-version trend, v1 heatmap, window distribution (index written).

Readme + metadata present and reference the upstream M2 windows path.

title: Verdict
text:
Minor nits / polish

Slug formatting: several plot filenames use the-count-that-coudnt (typo ‚Äúcoudnt‚Äù) and one has a trailing underscore (trend_coherence_the-count-that-coudnt_.png). Suggest normalizing slugs to avoid trailing underscores and fix the title case/typo if that‚Äôs accidental.
Bundler manifest parity: unlike Module 3, the bundle_index.json here doesn‚Äôt record per-parquet rows/cols/schema. Add those (as you did in M3) so QA can sanity-check contents without loading Parquet.
Seed disclosure: inference is effectively deterministic, but add seed: 7 (or null) in metadata for uniformity with earlier modules.
Cosine heatmaps: only v1 is rendered right now. Consider: render for each version (v1‚Äìv4) or at least the first and last to visualize drift.
Window plots cap: current set is reasonable; if articles grow, keep the per-article plot cap consistent with M1‚ÄìM3 (first 10 by slug) and note the cap in metadata.

title: Verdict
section: QA checks that passed (from the bundle)
text:
QA checks that passed (from the bundle)

uses_m2_windows: true, policy recorded and consistent.
normalize_embeddings: true ‚Üí cosine is well-behaved; violin/trend plots should never exceed 1.0.
No <2-sentence windows ‚Üí no unexpected NaNs in coherence_windows.parquet expected.
Plots exist and are non-empty (sizes look healthy in the archive).

title: Verdict
section: Suggested small additions to the notes (copy/paste)
text:
Suggested small additions to the notes (copy/paste)

Coherence metric is mean(off-diag cosine) over sentence embeddings (MiniLM-L6-v2, CPU, normalized).
Windows reuse Module 2 spans with full sentence containment; windows with <2 sentences are excluded (count = 0 in this run).
Bundle includes doc-level and window-level coherence plus global/ per-version visuals.
Known limitations: MiniLM is compact; for higher fidelity consider all-mpnet-base-v2 behind a flag (heavier).
Action item: add rows/cols/schema to bundle_index.json (align with Module 3), normalize slugs (remove trailing _, correct spelling), and optionally render heatmaps for v1 and v4.

If you want, I can also list the expected column set for each parquet (for a quick schema check in future runs).

Known limitations (explicit)

Parse-depth is model-dependent (small English pipeline); treat cross-domain comparisons cautiously.
Clause counting is a proxy (finite verbs + subord labels), not gold-standard clause parsing.
Discourse markers lexicon isn‚Äôt exhaustive; density TTR is a relative signal.

title: Add to Module-3 notes before moving on
text:
Environment & reproducibility

Uses spacy>=3.7,<3.8 with en_core_web_sm (NER excluded). First run may download the model.
CPU-only. Tunables via env:

LSA_SPACY_MAXLEN (default 2,000,000) for long docs
LSA_SPACY_PROCS (default 1) and LSA_SPACY_BATCH (default 16) for nlp.pipe

Wheels-first installs; base stack (NumPy/SciPy/etc.) left untouched.

title: Add to Module-3 notes before moving on
text:

Parsing & sentence statistics (how they‚Äôre computed)

Parser: en_core_web_sm with components except NER; sentence boundaries from spaCy.
Sentence depth: max head-distance from each token to the sentence root; per-sentence depth is the max over tokens.
Finite clause heuristic: counts tokens as finite predicates if (pos_ == "VERB" and not AUX) and (VerbForm=Fin in morph or tag_ ‚àà {VBD,VBP,VBZ}).
Coordination/subordination:

Subordination deps counted from: {mark, advcl, ccomp, xcomp, acl, relcl, csubj, csubjpass, csubj:pass}.
Coordination deps counted from: {cc, conj, parataxis}.
Reported as rates per token (coord_rate, subord_rate) and their ratio (coord_subord_ratio).

Metrics:

dm_types = number of distinct markers observed

Discourse markers: the default list is small; consider swapping to a richer, curated English DMs list (e.g., PDTB-style connectives) and supporting multi-lingual variants in a later module.
Alignment rule: full containment can yield zero-sentence windows near boundaries; acceptable for now, but we may add a ‚Äú‚â•X% overlap‚Äù policy if needed.

def token_zipf_stats(tokens):
    lowers = [t.lower() for t in tokens]
    # cache unique lookups
    uniq = sorted(set(lowers))
    freq_map = {t: zipf_frequency(t, 'en', wordlist='best') for t in uniq}
    freqs = [freq_map[t] for t in lowers if freq_map[t] is not None and freq_map[t] > 0]

Guard histogram memory (avoid storing all values for giant corpora):

# after computing freqs for a doc
MAX_KEEP = 500_000  # tokens kept globally for ZIPF_ALL
if len(freqs):
    if 'ZIPF_ALL' not in globals() or getattr(ZIPF_ALL, 'size', 0) == 0:
        ZIPF_ALL = np.asarray(freqs, dtype=float)
    else:
        # reservoir-like downsample to bound memory
        if ZIPF_ALL.size < MAX_KEEP:
            ZIPF_ALL = np.concatenate([ZIPF_ALL, np.asarray(freqs, dtype=float)])

MODULE_STATUS: Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]] = {}

def report_status(module: str, ok: bool, note: str = "", extra: Optional[Dict[str,Any]] = None):

# cell 0.5: foundations: offset-preserving normalization (encoding/whitespace)
# Goal: normalize newlines, collapse excessive spaces, NFKC unicode, while keeping a map from
# normalized index -> original index so later segments can trace exact spans.
from typing import NamedTuple

class NormResult(NamedTuple):
    text: str
    norm_to_orig: List[int]  # index i in normalized -> index in original
    orig_to_norm: List[int]  # index j in original   -> nearest normalized index

def normalize_with_offsets(s: str) -> NormResult:
    norm_to_orig: List[int] = []
    out_chars: List[str] = []
    i = 0
    prev_space = False
    for j, ch in enumerate(s):
        ch_n = unicodedata.normalize("NFKC", ch)
        # Normalize line endings to \n
        if ch_n in ["\r", "\u2028", "\u2029"]:
            ch_n = "\n"
        # Collapse runs of whitespace to single spaces, but preserve newlines
        if ch_n.isspace() and ch_n != "\n":
            if prev_space:
                continue
            ch_n = " "
            prev_space = True
        else:
            prev_space = False
        out_chars.append(ch_n)
        norm_to_orig.append(j)
        i += 1

    text = "".join(out_chars)

    # Build reverse map (approximate, nearest-left)
    orig_to_norm = [-1] * len(s)
    for norm_i, orig_j in enumerate(norm_to_orig):
        if 0 <= orig_j < len(s):
            orig_to_norm[orig_j] = norm_i
    last = -1
    for j in range(len(s)):
        if orig_to_norm[j] == -1:
            orig_to_norm[j] = last
        else:
            last = orig_to_norm[j]

    return NormResult(text=text, norm_to_orig=norm_to_orig, orig_to_norm=orig_to_norm)

# Quick sanity check
try:
    demo = "A  test\u00A0string\rwith\rmixed  spaces.\nNext line."
    res = normalize_with_offsets(demo)
    assert isinstance(res.text, str) and len(res.norm_to_orig) == len(res.text)
    print("Offset-preserving normalization ready.")
    report_status("0.foundation.normalize", True, "Normalization functions available")
except Exception as e:

# cell 0.6: foundations: sentence segmentation & windowing (regex heuristic, no external deps)
SENT_SPLIT_RE = re.compile(r'(?<!\b[A-Z])[.!?]\s+(?=[A-Z0-9])')

def split_sentences(text: str) -> List[Tuple[str, Tuple[int,int]]]:
    # Return list of (sentence, (start_idx, end_idx)) in normalized text
    spans: List[Tuple[int,int]] = []
    start = 0
    for m in SENT_SPLIT_RE.finditer(text):
        end = m.start() + 1  # include the punctuation
        spans.append((start, end))
        start = m.end()
    # tail
    if start < len(text):
        spans.append((start, len(text)))
    sents = [(text[a:b], (a,b)) for a,b in spans if b > a]
    return sents

def window_sentences(sents: List[Tuple[str, Tuple[int,int]]], win: int, stride: int):
    windows = []
    for i in range(0, max(len(sents)-win+1, 0), stride):
        chunk = sents[i:i+win]
        if len(chunk) < win:
            break
        text = " ".join(x[0].strip() for x in chunk)
        start = chunk[0][1][0]; end = chunk[-1][1][1]
        windows.append({
            "sent_start_idx": i,
            "sent_end_idx": i+win,
            "char_span": [start, end],
            "text": text
        })
    return windows

# Smoke test on a tiny sample

# Determinism (CPU-only)

# cell 0.4: foundations: status logging & self-reporting
MODULE_STATUS: Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]] = {}

def report_status(module: str, ok: bool, note: str = "", extra: Optional[Dict[str,Any]] = None):
    MODULE_STATUS[module] = {
        "ok": bool(ok),
        "note": note,
        "extra": extra or {},
        "ts": datetime.datetime.utcnow().isoformat() + "Z",
    }
    print(f"[{module}] status: {'OK' if ok else 'DEFERRED/FAIL'} ‚Äî {note}")

def dump_status_json(out_path: Path = paths.out_dir / "module_status.json"):
    out_path.write_text(json.dumps(MODULE_STATUS, indent=2), encoding="utf-8")
    print("Wrote module status to:", out_path)
# cell 0.5: foundations: offset-preserving normalization (encoding/whitespace)
# Goal: normalize newlines, collapse excessive spaces, NFKC unicode, while keeping a map from
# normalized index -> original index so later segments can trace exact spans.
from typing import NamedTuple

class NormResult(NamedTuple):
    text: str
    norm_to_orig: List[int]  # index i in normalized -> index in original
    orig_to_norm: List[int]  # index j in original   -> nearest normalized index

def normalize_with_offsets(s: str) -> NormResult:
    norm_to_orig: List[int] = []
    out_chars: List[str] = []
    i = 0
    prev_space = False
    for j, ch in enumerate(s):
        ch_n = unicodedata.normalize("NFKC", ch)
        # Normalize line endings to \n
        if ch_n in ["\r", "\u2028", "\u2029"]:
            ch_n = "\n"
        # Collapse runs of whitespace to single spaces, but preserve newlines
        if ch_n.isspace() and ch_n != "\n":
            if prev_space:
                continue
            ch_n = " "
            prev_space = True
        else:
            prev_space = False
        out_chars.append(ch_n)
        norm_to_orig.append(j)
        i += 1

    text = "".join(out_chars)

    # Build reverse map (approximate, nearest-left)
    orig_to_norm = [-1] * len(s)
    for norm_i, orig_j in enumerate(norm_to_orig):
        if 0 <= orig_j < len(s):
            orig_to_norm[orig_j] = norm_i
    last = -1
    for j in range(len(s)):
        if orig_to_norm[j] == -1:
            orig_to_norm[j] = last
        else:
            last = orig_to_norm[j]

    return NormResult(text=text, norm_to_orig=norm_to_orig, orig_to_norm=orig_to_norm)

# Quick sanity check
try:
    demo = "A  test\u00A0string\rwith\rmixed  spaces.\nNext line."
    res = normalize_with_offsets(demo)
    assert isinstance(res.text, str) and len(res.norm_to_orig) == len(res.text)
    print("Offset-preserving normalization ready.")
    report_status("0.foundation.normalize", True, "Normalization functions available")
except Exception as e:
    report_status("0.foundation.normalize", False, f"Init error: {e}")
# cell 0.6: foundations: sentence segmentation & windowing (regex heuristic, no external deps)
SENT_SPLIT_RE = re.compile(r'(?<!\b[A-Z])[.!?]\s+(?=[A-Z0-9])')

def split_sentences(text: str) -> List[Tuple[str, Tuple[int,int]]]:
    # Return list of (sentence, (start_idx, end_idx)) in normalized text
    spans: List[Tuple[int,int]] = []
    start = 0
    for m in SENT_SPLIT_RE.finditer(text):
        end = m.start() + 1  # include the punctuation
        spans.append((start, end))
        start = m.end()
    # tail
    if start < len(text):
        spans.append((start, len(text)))
    sents = [(text[a:b], (a,b)) for a,b in spans if b > a]
    return sents

def window_sentences(sents: List[Tuple[str, Tuple[int,int]]], win: int, stride: int):
    windows = []
    for i in range(0, max(len(sents)-win+1, 0), stride):
        chunk = sents[i:i+win]
        if len(chunk) < win:
            break
        text = " ".join(x[0].strip() for x in chunk)
        start = chunk[0][1][0]; end = chunk[-1][1][1]
        windows.append({
            "sent_start_idx": i,
            "sent_end_idx": i+win,
            "char_span": [start, end],
            "text": text
        })
    return windows

# Smoke test on a tiny sample
try:
    sample = "First sentence. Second sentence! Third sentence? Fourth one. Fifth here."
    sents = split_sentences(sample)
    wins = window_sentences(sents, cfg.window_sentences, cfg.window_stride)
    print(f"Sents: {len(sents)}, Windows: {len(wins)}")

except Exception as e:

def _get_version(pkg: str):

from typing import NamedTuple

class NormResult(NamedTuple):
    text: str
    norm_to_orig: List[int]
    orig_to_norm: List[int]

def normalize_with_offsets(s: str) -> NormResult:
    norm_to_orig: List[int] = []
    out_chars: List[str] = []
    prev_space = False
    j = 0
    L = len(s)

    while j < L:
        ch = s[j]
        if ch == '\r':
            if j + 1 < L and s[j+1] == '\n':
                out_chars.append('\n'); norm_to_orig.append(j)
                prev_space = False; j += 2; continue
            else:

        else:
            ch_n = unicodedata.normalize("NFKC", ch)

            ch_n = " "; prev_space = True
        else:
            prev_space = (ch_n == " ")

        out_chars.append(ch_n); norm_to_orig.append(j); j += 1

    text = "".join(out_chars)
    orig_to_norm = [-1] * L
    for norm_i, orig_j in enumerate(norm_to_orig):
        if 0 <= orig_j < L:
            orig_to_norm[orig_j] = norm_i
    last = 0
    for k in range(L):
        if orig_to_norm[k] == -1:
            orig_to_norm[k] = last
        else:
            last = orig_to_norm[k]

    return NormResult(text=text, norm_to_orig=norm_to_orig, orig_to_norm=orig_to_norm)

SENT_SPLIT_RE = re.compile(r'(?<!\b[A-Z])[.!?]\s+(?=[A-Z0-9])')

def split_sentences(text: str) -> List[Tuple[str, Tuple[int,int]]]:
    spans: List[Tuple[int,int]] = []
    start = 0
    for m in SENT_SPLIT_RE.finditer(text):
        end = m.start() + 1
        spans.append((start, end))
        start = m.end()
    if start < len(text): spans.append((start, len(text)))
    return [(text[a:b], (a,b)) for a,b in spans if b > a]

def window_sentences(sents: List[Tuple[str, Tuple[int,int]]], win: int, stride: int):
    windows = []

from typing import NamedTuple

class NormResult(NamedTuple):
    text: str
    norm_to_orig: List[int]
    orig_to_norm: List[int]

def normalize_with_offsets(s: str) -> NormResult:
    norm_to_orig: List[int] = []
    out_chars: List[str] = []
    prev_space = False
    j = 0
    L = len(s)

    while j < L:
        ch = s[j]
        if ch == '\r':
            if j + 1 < L and s[j+1] == '\n':
                out_chars.append('\n'); norm_to_orig.append(j)
                prev_space = False; j += 2; continue
            else:
                ch_n = '\n'
        else:
            ch_n = unicodedata.normalize("NFKC", ch)
            if ch_n in ["\u2028", "\u2029"]:
                ch_n = "\n"

        if ch_n.isspace() and ch_n != "\n":
            if prev_space: j += 1; continue
            ch_n = " "; prev_space = True
        else:
            prev_space = (ch_n == " ")

        out_chars.append(ch_n); norm_to_orig.append(j); j += 1

    text = "".join(out_chars)
    orig_to_norm = [-1] * L
    for norm_i, orig_j in enumerate(norm_to_orig):
        if 0 <= orig_j < L:
            orig_to_norm[orig_j] = norm_i
    last = 0
    for k in range(L):
        if orig_to_norm[k] == -1:
            orig_to_norm[k] = last
        else:
            last = orig_to_norm[k]

    return NormResult(text=text, norm_to_orig=norm_to_orig, orig_to_norm=orig_to_norm)

SENT_SPLIT_RE = re.compile(r'(?<!\b[A-Z]\.)(?<=[.!?])\s+(?=[A-Z0-9])')

def split_sentences(text: str) -> List[Tuple[str, Tuple[int,int]]]:
    spans: List[Tuple[int,int]] = []
    start = 0
    for m in SENT_SPLIT_RE.finditer(text):
        end = m.start() + 1
        spans.append((start, end))
        start = m.end()
    if start < len(text): spans.append((start, len(text)))
    return [(text[a:b], (a,b)) for a,b in spans if b > a]

def window_sentences(sents: List[Tuple[str, Tuple[int,int]]], win: int, stride: int):
    windows = []
    for i in range(0, max(len(sents)-win+1, 0), stride):
        chunk = sents[i:i+win]
        if len(chunk) < win: break
        text = " ".join(x[0].strip() for x in chunk)
        start = chunk[0][1][0]; end = chunk[-1][1][1]
        windows.append({"sent_start_idx": i, "sent_end_idx": i+win, "char_span": [start,end], "text": text})
    return windows

import re

# cell 1.4: wordfreq: Zipf frequency features
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import regex as rxx
from wordfreq import zipf_frequency
from pathlib import Path
import json

# Unicode-aware token pattern: letters/marks/numbers + common apostrophes/hyphens
TOKEN_RE = rxx.compile(r"\b[\p{L}\p{M}\p{N}‚Äô'-]+\b", flags=rxx.UNICODE)

def tokenize(text: str):
    return [m.group(0) for m in TOKEN_RE.finditer(text or "")]

def token_zipf_stats(tokens):
    # Lowercase for frequency lookup; keep lengths on raw tokens for separate stats
    lowers = [t.lower() for t in tokens]
    freqs = [zipf_frequency(t, 'en', wordlist='best') for t in lowers]
    # Treat 0 or None as missing
    freqs = [f for f in freqs if f is not None and f > 0]
    if len(freqs) == 0:
        return {
            "zipf_mean": np.nan, "zipf_std": np.nan,
            "zipf_p25": np.nan, "zipf_p50": np.nan, "zipf_p75": np.nan,
            "rare_rate": np.nan, "mid_rate": np.nan, "common_rate": np.nan
        }, []
    arr = np.asarray(freqs, dtype=float)
    # Buckets: rare <3.0, mid [3.0,5.0), common >=5.0
    rare = float(np.mean(arr < 3.0))
    mid  = float(np.mean((arr >= 3.0) & (arr < 5.0)))
    com  = float(np.mean(arr >= 5.0))
    stats = {
        "zipf_mean": float(np.mean(arr)),
        "zipf_std": float(np.std(arr, ddof=0)),
        "zipf_p25": float(np.percentile(arr, 25)),
        "zipf_p50": float(np.percentile(arr, 50)),
        "zipf_p75": float(np.percentile(arr, 75)),
        "rare_rate": rare, "mid_rate": mid, "common_rate": com
    }
    return stats, arr

# Language heuristic: latin vs. non-latin alpha ratio
def latin_alpha_ratio(text: str) -> float:
    if not text: return 0.0
    all_alpha = [ch for ch in text if ch.isalpha()]
    if not all_alpha: return 0.0
    latin = [ch for ch in all_alpha if ('A' <= ch <= 'Z') or ('a' <= ch <= 'z')]
    return len(latin) / len(all_alpha)

# Collectors for visuals
ZIPF_ALL = []  # all token zipf values across docs (for histogram)

rows = []
for d in DOCS:
    doc_id, text = str(d["doc_id"]), (d.get("text") or "")
    toks = tokenize(text)
    stats, freqs = token_zipf_stats(toks)
    rows.append({"doc_id": doc_id, **stats})
    if len(freqs): ZIPF_ALL.append(np.asarray(freqs, dtype=float))

# Merge into df_lex
df_zipf = pd.DataFrame(rows)
df_lex = df_lex.merge(df_zipf, on="doc_id", how="left")

# Update metadata with language heuristic (non-blocking)
meta_path = Path("outputs/textstat_lex/metadata.json")
meta = json.loads(meta_path.read_text(encoding="utf-8"))
try:
    ratios = [latin_alpha_ratio(d.get("text") or "") for d in DOCS]
    # flag if most docs look non-latin
    if len(ratios) and float(np.mean([r < 0.5 for r in ratios])) > 0.5:
        meta["lang_guess"] = "non_en_possible"
    meta_path.write_text(json.dumps(meta, indent=2), encoding="utf-8")
except Exception:
    # never fail the module on heuristic update
    pass

# Flatten ZIPF_ALL for plotting in 1.6
ZIPF_ALL = np.concatenate(ZIPF_ALL, axis=0) if len(ZIPF_ALL) else np.array([], dtype=float)

print({"cell_id": "cell 1.4: wordfreq: Zipf frequency features",
       "status": "pass", "docs": len(df_zipf), "zipf_values": int(ZIPF_ALL.size)})
# cell 1.5: lexicons: function-word profile & TTR
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path
import regex as rxx

# Reuse tokenizer from 1.4 (redefine defensively for standalone runs)
TOKEN_RE = rxx.compile(r"\b[\p{L}\p{M}\p{N}‚Äô'-]+\b", flags=rxx.UNICODE)
def tokenize(text: str):
    return [m.group(0) for m in TOKEN_RE.finditer(text or "")]

# Load function-word list or fallback
LEX_PATH = Path("lexicons/function_words_en.txt")
if LEX_PATH.exists():
    FUNC_WORDS = {w.strip().lower() for w in LEX_PATH.read_text(encoding="utf-8").splitlines() if w.strip()}
else:
    FUNC_WORDS = {
        # Minimal fallback (~60 items across common categories)
        "a","an","the","and","or","but","if","because","as","until","while",
        "of","at","by","for","with","about","against","between","into","through",
        "during","before","after","above","below","to","from","up","down","in","out",
        "on","off","over","under","again","further","then","once","here","there",
        "when","where","why","how","all","any","both","each","few","more","most",
        "other","some","such","no","nor","not","only","own","same","so","than","too","very",
        "can","will","just","don","should","now","i","you","he","she","it","we","they",
        "me","him","her","us","them","my","your","his","its","our","their",
        "is","am","are","was","were","be","been","being","have","has","had","do","does","did"
    }

PUNCT_CHARS = set(list(".,;:!?‚Äî‚Äì-()[]'\"‚Äú‚Äù‚Äò‚Äô"))

def punct_density(text: str, token_count: int) -> float:
    if token_count <= 0: return float("nan")
    count = sum(1 for ch in (text or "") if ch in PUNCT_CHARS)
    return (count / token_count) * 100.0

# Na√Øve sentence split for per-sentence token lengths (plots only)
SENT_SPLIT_FOR_STATS = rxx.compile(r"(?<=[.!?])\s+(?=[A-Z])")

SENT_LEN_ALL = []  # for histogram across all docs

rows = []
for d in DOCS:
    doc_id, text = str(d["doc_id"]), (d.get("text") or "")
    toks = tokenize(text)
    n_tokens = int(len(toks))
    lowers = [t.lower() for t in toks]
    n_unique = len(set(lowers))
    ttr = float(n_unique / n_tokens) if n_tokens > 0 else float("nan")
    fw_rate = float(sum(1 for t in lowers if t in FUNC_WORDS) / n_tokens) if n_tokens > 0 else float("nan")
    tok_lens = np.array([len(t) for t in toks], dtype=float) if n_tokens > 0 else np.array([], dtype=float)
    token_len_mean = float(tok_lens.mean()) if tok_lens.size else float("nan")
    token_len_std  = float(tok_lens.std(ddof=0)) if tok_lens.size else float("nan")
    pden = punct_density(text, n_tokens)

    # Sentence stats for plots (not used for later "syntactic" evidence)
    sents = [s for s in SENT_SPLIT_FOR_STATS.split(text.strip()) if s]
    sent_lens = [len(tokenize(s)) for s in sents] if sents else []
    if sent_lens: SENT_LEN_ALL.extend(sent_lens)
    naive_sentence_count = int(len(sents))
    naive_sentence_len_mean = float(np.mean(sent_lens)) if sent_lens else float("nan")
    naive_sentence_len_std  = float(np.std(sent_lens, ddof=0)) if sent_lens else float("nan")

    rows.append({
        "doc_id": doc_id,
        "n_tokens_regex": n_tokens,
        "ttr": ttr,
        "function_word_rate": fw_rate,
        "punctuation_density_per_100toks": pden,
        "token_len_mean": token_len_mean,
        "token_len_std": token_len_std,
        "naive_sentence_count": naive_sentence_count,
        "naive_sentence_len_mean": naive_sentence_len_mean,
        "naive_sentence_len_std": naive_sentence_len_std,
    })

df_lex2 = pd.DataFrame(rows)

# Merge into df_lex and coerce dtypes per contract
df_lex = df_lex.merge(df_lex2, on="doc_id", how="left")

# Reorder/ensure required columns exist; Parquet may reorder, but set + dtypes must match
required_cols = [
    "doc_id","n_chars","n_tokens_regex","ttr","function_word_rate","punctuation_density_per_100toks",
    "token_len_mean","token_len_std","zipf_mean","zipf_std","zipf_p25","zipf_p50","zipf_p75",
    "rare_rate","mid_rate","common_rate","flesch_reading_ease","flesch_kincaid_grade","gunning_fog",
    "smog_index","coleman_liau_index","automated_readability_index","dale_chall_readability_score",
    "linsear_write_formula","text_standard","naive_sentence_count","naive_sentence_len_mean",
    "naive_sentence_len_std"
]
for c in required_cols:
    if c not in df_lex.columns:
        df_lex[c] = np.nan

# Dtype enforcement
df_lex["doc_id"] = df_lex["doc_id"].astype("string")
for c in ["n_chars","n_tokens_regex","naive_sentence_count"]:
    # Missing ints default to 0 (contract prefers int64; NaN not allowed for ints)
    df_lex[c] = df_lex[c].fillna(0).astype("int64")
df_lex["text_standard"] = df_lex["text_standard"].astype("string")

float_cols = [c for c in required_cols if c not in ["doc_id","n_chars","n_tokens_regex","naive_sentence_count","text_standard"]]

FNAME_RE = re.compile(r"^(?P<prefix>0[1-4])-(?P<slug>.+)\.md$")

def _clean_markdown(s: str) -> str:
    """Regex-only light cleaner for readability/lexical metrics."""
    if not s: return ""
    # strip fenced code blocks (``` ... ```)
    s = re.sub(r"```[\s\S]*?```", " ", s)
    # images ![alt](url) -> alt
    s = re.sub(r"!\[([^\]]*)\]\([^)]+\)", r"\1", s)
    # links [text](url) -> text
    s = re.sub(r"\[([^\]]+)\]\([^)]+\)", r"\1", s)
    # inline code `code`
    s = re.sub(r"`([^`]+)`", r"\1", s)
    # headings ^#{1,6}\s+
    s = re.sub(r"^\s*#{1,6}\s+", "", s, flags=re.MULTILINE)
    # collapse whitespace
    s = re.sub(r"[ \t]+", " ", s)
    s = re.sub(r"\s*\n\s*", "\n", s).strip()
    return s

import regex as rxx
from wordfreq import zipf_frequency

TOKEN_RE = rxx.compile(r"\b[\p{L}\p{M}\p{N}‚Äô'-]+\b", flags=rxx.UNICODE)

def tokenize(text: str):
    return [m.group(0) for m in TOKEN_RE.finditer(text or "")]

def token_zipf_stats(tokens):
    lowers = [t.lower() for t in tokens]
    freqs = [zipf_frequency(t, 'en', wordlist='best') for t in lowers]
    freqs = [f for f in freqs if f is not None and f > 0]
    if len(freqs) == 0:
        return {
            "zipf_mean": np.nan, "zipf_std": np.nan,
            "zipf_p25": np.nan, "zipf_p50": np.nan, "zipf_p75": np.nan,
            "rare_rate": np.nan, "mid_rate": np.nan, "common_rate": np.nan
        }, []
    arr = np.asarray(freqs, dtype=float)
    stats = {
        "zipf_mean": float(np.mean(arr)),
        "zipf_std": float(np.std(arr, ddof=0)),
        "zipf_p25": float(np.percentile(arr, 25)),
        "zipf_p50": float(np.percentile(arr, 50)),
        "zipf_p75": float(np.percentile(arr, 75)),
        "rare_rate": float(np.mean(arr < 3.0)),
        "mid_rate":  float(np.mean((arr >= 3.0) & (arr < 5.0))),
        "common_rate": float(np.mean(arr >= 5.0)),
    }
    return stats, arr

def latin_alpha_ratio(text: str) -> float:
    if not text: return 0.0
    all_alpha = [ch for ch in text if ch.isalpha()]
    if not all_alpha: return 0.0
    latin = [ch for ch in all_alpha if ('A' <= ch <= 'Z') or ('a' <= ch <= 'z')]
    return len(latin) / len(all_alpha)

def _token_set(text: str) -> set:
    return set([m.group(0).lower() for m in TOKEN_RE.finditer(text or "")])

def token_jaccard(a_text: str, b_text: str) -> float:
    A, B = _token_set(a_text), _token_set(b_text)
    if not A and not B: return float("nan")
    inter = len(A & B); uni = len(A | B)
    return inter / uni if uni else float("nan")

def js_divergence(p, q, eps=1e-8):
    p = np.asarray(p, dtype=float) + eps
    q = np.asarray(q, dtype=float) + eps
    p /= p.sum(); q /= q.sum()
    m = 0.5 * (p + q)
    kl = lambda x, y: np.sum(x * np.log(x / y))
    return float(0.5 * kl(p, m) + 0.5 * kl(q, m))

FNAME_RE = re.compile(r"^(?P<prefix>0[1-4])-(?P<slug>.+)\.md$")

def _clean_markdown(s: str) -> str:
    """Regex-only light cleaner for readability/lexical metrics."""
    if not s: return ""
    s = re.sub(r"```[\s\S]*?```", " ", s)                            # fenced code blocks
    s = re.sub(r"!\[([^\]]*)\]\([^)]+\)", r"\1", s)                  # images -> alt
    s = re.sub(r"\[([^\]]+)\]\([^)]+\)", r"\1", s)                   # links -> text
    s = re.sub(r"`([^`]+)`", r"\1", s)                               # inline code
    s = re.sub(r"^\s*#{1,6}\s+", "", s, flags=re.MULTILINE)          # headings
    s = re.sub(r"[ \t]+", " ", s)                                    # spaces
    s = re.sub(r"\s*\n\s*", "\n", s).strip()                         # newlines

    files = [p for p in SOURCE_DIR.iterdir() if p.is_file() and FNAME_RE.match(p.name)]
    if not files:

# ---- Deltas between consecutive versions within each article ----
def _token_set(text: str) -> set:
    return set([m.group(0).lower() for m in TOKEN_RE.finditer(text or "")])

def token_jaccard(a_text: str, b_text: str) -> float:
    A, B = _token_set(a_text), _token_set(b_text)
    if not A and not B: return float("nan")
    inter = len(A & B); uni = len(A | B)
    return inter / uni if uni else float("nan")

def js_divergence(p, q, eps=1e-8):
    p = np.asarray(p, dtype=float) + eps
    q = np.asarray(q, dtype=float) + eps
    p /= p.sum(); q /= q.sum()
    m = 0.5 * (p + q)
    kl = lambda x, y: np.sum(x * np.log(x / y))
    return float(0.5 * kl(p, m) + 0.5 * kl(q, m))

                "token_jaccard": token_jaccard(text_map.get(docA,""), text_map.get(docB,"")),

    columns=["article_id","from_version","to_version","token_jaccard","zipf_jsd"])

# ---- Deltas between consecutive versions within each article ----
def _token_set(text: str) -> set:
    return set([m.group(0).lower() for m in TOKEN_RE.finditer(text or "")])

def token_jaccard(a_text: str, b_text: str) -> float:
    A, B = _token_set(a_text), _token_set(b_text)
    if not A and not B: return float("nan")
    inter = len(A & B); uni = len(A | B)
    return inter / uni if uni else float("nan")

def js_divergence(p, q, eps=1e-8):
    p = np.asarray(p, dtype=float) + eps
    q = np.asarray(q, dtype=float) + eps
    p /= p.sum(); q /= q.sum()
    m = 0.5 * (p + q)
    kl = lambda x, y: np.sum(x * np.log(x / y))
    return float(0.5 * kl(p, m) + 0.5 * kl(q, m))

                "from_version": int(v_from),
                "to_version": int(v_to),
                "token_jaccard": token_jaccard(text_map.get(docA,""), text_map.get(docB,"")),
                "zipf_jsd": js_divergence(p, q),
            })

df_deltas = pd.DataFrame(delta_rows) if delta_rows else pd.DataFrame(
    columns=["article_id","from_version","to_version","token_jaccard","zipf_jsd"])

def _clean_markdown(s: str) -> str:
    """Regex-only light cleaner for readability/lexical metrics."""
    if not s: return ""
    s = re.sub(r"```[\s\S]*?```", " ", s)                            # fenced code blocks
    s = re.sub(r"!\[([^\]]*)\]\([^)]+\)", r"\1", s)                  # images -> alt
    s = re.sub(r"\[([^\]]+)\]\([^)]+\)", r"\1", s)                   # links -> text
    s = re.sub(r"`([^`]+)`", r"\1", s)                               # inline code
    s = re.sub(r"^\s*#{1,6}\s+", "", s, flags=re.MULTILINE)          # headings
    s = re.sub(r"[ \t]+", " ", s)                                    # spaces
    s = re.sub(r"\s*\n\s*", "\n", s).strip()                         # newlines
    return s

# cell 1.4: wordfreq: Zipf frequency features (Unicode-aware, regex-only tokenization)
import regex as rxx
from wordfreq import zipf_frequency

TOKEN_RE = rxx.compile(r"\b[\p{L}\p{M}\p{N}‚Äô'-]+\b", flags=rxx.UNICODE)

def tokenize(text: str):
    return [m.group(0) for m in TOKEN_RE.finditer(text or "")]

def token_zipf_stats(tokens):
    lowers = [t.lower() for t in tokens]
    freqs = [zipf_frequency(t, 'en', wordlist='best') for t in lowers]
    freqs = [f for f in freqs if f is not None and f > 0]
    if len(freqs) == 0:
        return {
            "zipf_mean": np.nan, "zipf_std": np.nan,
            "zipf_p25": np.nan, "zipf_p50": np.nan, "zipf_p75": np.nan,
            "rare_rate": np.nan, "mid_rate": np.nan, "common_rate": np.nan
        }, []
    arr = np.asarray(freqs, dtype=float)
    stats = {
        "zipf_mean": float(np.mean(arr)),
        "zipf_std": float(np.std(arr, ddof=0)),
        "zipf_p25": float(np.percentile(arr, 25)),
        "zipf_p50": float(np.percentile(arr, 50)),
        "zipf_p75": float(np.percentile(arr, 75)),
        "rare_rate": float(np.mean(arr < 3.0)),
        "mid_rate":  float(np.mean((arr >= 3.0) & (arr < 5.0))),
        "common_rate": float(np.mean(arr >= 5.0)),
    }
    return stats, arr

def latin_alpha_ratio(text: str) -> float:
    if not text: return 0.0
    all_alpha = [ch for ch in text if ch.isalpha()]
    if not all_alpha: return 0.0
    latin = [ch for ch in all_alpha if ('A' <= ch <= 'Z') or ('a' <= ch <= 'z')]
    return len(latin) / len(all_alpha)

ZIPF_ALL = []
zipf_rows = []
for idx, d in enumerate(DOCS):
    doc_id, text = str(d.get("doc_id", f"doc_{idx:04d}")), (d.get("text") or "")
    toks = tokenize(text)
    stats, freqs = token_zipf_stats(toks)
    zipf_rows.append({"doc_id": doc_id, **stats})
    if len(freqs): ZIPF_ALL.append(np.asarray(freqs, dtype=float))

df_zipf = pd.DataFrame(zipf_rows)

        "during","before","after","above","below","to","from","up","down","in","out",

        "me","him","her","us","them","my","your","his","its","our","their",
        "is","am","are","was","were","be","been","being","have","has","had","do","does","did"
    }

PUNCT_CHARS = set(list(".,;:!?‚Äî‚Äì-()[]'\"‚Äú‚Äù‚Äò‚Äô"))
SENT_SPLIT_FOR_STATS = rxx.compile(r"(?<=[.!?])\s+(?=[A-Z])")

SENT_LEN_ALL = []
rows = []
for idx, d in enumerate(DOCS):
    doc_id, text = str(d.get("doc_id", f"doc_{idx:04d}")), (d.get("text") or "")
    toks = tokenize(text)
    n_tokens = int(len(toks))
    lowers = [t.lower() for t in toks]
    n_unique = len(set(lowers))
    ttr = float(n_unique / n_tokens) if n_tokens > 0 else float("nan")
    fw_rate = float(sum(1 for t in lowers if t in FUNC_WORDS) / n_tokens) if n_tokens > 0 else float("nan")
    tok_lens = np.array([len(t) for t in toks], dtype=float) if n_tokens > 0 else np.array([], dtype=float)
    token_len_mean = float(tok_lens.mean()) if tok_lens.size else float("nan")
    token_len_std  = float(tok_lens.std(ddof=0)) if tok_lens.size else float("nan")
    pden = (sum(1 for ch in (text or "") if ch in PUNCT_CHARS) / n_tokens * 100.0) if n_tokens > 0 else float("nan")

    sents = [s for s in SENT_SPLIT_FOR_STATS.split(text.strip()) if s]
    sent_lens = [len(tokenize(s)) for s in sents] if sents else []
    if sent_lens: SENT_LEN_ALL.extend(sent_lens)
    naive_sentence_count = int(len(sents))
    naive_sentence_len_mean = float(np.mean(sent_lens)) if sent_lens else float("nan")
    naive_sentence_len_std  = float(np.std(sent_lens, ddof=0)) if sent_lens else float("nan")

            except Exception as e:

parquet_path = BASE_OUT / "lexical_features.parquet"

# ---- Deltas between consecutive versions within each article ----
def _token_set(text: str) -> set:
    return set([m.group(0).lower() for m in TOKEN_RE.finditer(text or "")])

def token_jaccard(a_text: str, b_text: str) -> float:
    A, B = _token_set(a_text), _token_set(b_text)
    if not A and not B: return float("nan")
    inter = len(A & B); uni = len(A | B)
    return inter / uni if uni else float("nan")

def js_divergence(p, q, eps=1e-8):
    p = np.asarray(p, dtype=float) + eps
    q = np.asarray(q, dtype=float) + eps
    p /= p.sum(); q /= q.sum()
    m = 0.5 * (p + q)
    kl = lambda x, y: np.sum(x * np.log(x / y))
    return float(0.5 * kl(p, m) + 0.5 * kl(q, m))

delta_rows = []
if "article_id" in df_lex.columns and df_lex["article_id"].notna().any():
    # need access to original cleaned text for jaccard; rebuild map from DOCS
    text_map = {d.get("doc_id", f"doc_{i:04d}"): d.get("text","") for i,d in enumerate(DOCS)}
    for slug in sorted(df_lex["article_id"].dropna().unique()):
        sub = df_lex[df_lex["article_id"] == slug].copy().sort_values("version_id")

            delta_rows.append({
                "article_id": slug,
                "from_version": int(v_from),
                "to_version": int(v_to),
                "token_jaccard": token_jaccard(text_map.get(docA,""), text_map.get(docB,"")),
                "zipf_jsd": js_divergence(p, q),
            })

df_deltas = pd.DataFrame(delta_rows) if delta_rows else pd.DataFrame(
    columns=["article_id","from_version","to_version","token_jaccard","zipf_jsd"])
deltas_path = BASE_OUT / "lexical_deltas.parquet"
df_deltas.to_parquet(deltas_path, index=False, engine="pyarrow")

# cell 2.2: NLTK: imports & tokenizer init (filename-prefix discovery compatible)
import json, re, random, datetime
from pathlib import Path

# Foundations must already be imported in 0.2
_missing = [name for name in ("np","pd","plt") if name not in globals()]
if _missing:
    raise RuntimeError(f"Foundations not loaded (missing {_missing}). Run cell 0.2 before Module 2.")

import nltk
from nltk.tokenize import sent_tokenize, TreebankWordTokenizer
from nltk.corpus import stopwords
import regex as rxx

np.random.seed(7); random.seed(7)

# ---- Input handshake (reuse DOCS/TEXT if already present; else filename-driven discovery) ----
g = globals()
DOCS = g.get("DOCS"); TEXT = g.get("TEXT")
SOURCE_DIR = Path(g.get("SOURCE_DIR", "content"))  # same default as Module 1
FNAME_RE = re.compile(r"^(?P<prefix>0[1-4])-(?P<slug>.+)\.md$")
NOTES = []

def _clean_markdown(s: str) -> str:
    if not s: return ""
    s = re.sub(r"```[\s\S]*?```", " ", s)
    s = re.sub(r"!\[([^\]]*)\]\([^)]+\)", r"\1", s)
    s = re.sub(r"\[([^\]]+)\]\([^)]+\)", r"\1", s)
    s = re.sub(r"`([^`]+)`", r"\1", s)
    s = re.sub(r"^\s*#{1,6}\s+", "", s, flags=re.MULTILINE)
    s = re.sub(r"[ \t]+", " ", s)
    s = re.sub(r"\s*\n\s*", "\n", s).strip()
    return s

if DOCS is None and TEXT is not None:
    DOCS = [{"article_id":"doc_0001","version_id":1,"version_tag":"v1",
             "filename":"<in-memory>","path":"<in-memory>",
             "doc_id":"doc_0001::v1","text":_clean_markdown(TEXT)}]
elif DOCS is None and TEXT is None:
    if not SOURCE_DIR.exists() or not SOURCE_DIR.is_dir():
        raise ValueError(f"Module 2: SOURCE_DIR does not exist or is not a directory: {SOURCE_DIR}")
    files = [p for p in SOURCE_DIR.iterdir() if p.is_file() and FNAME_RE.match(p.name)]
    if not files:
        raise ValueError("Module 2: No files found matching ^(0[1-4])-(.+)\\.md$ in SOURCE_DIR.")
    groups = {}
    for p in files:
        m = FNAME_RE.match(p.name); prefix, slug = m.group("prefix"), m.group("slug")
        vid = int(prefix); grp = groups.setdefault(slug, {})
        if vid in grp: raise ValueError(f"Duplicate version prefix for article '{slug}': {prefix}")
        grp[vid] = p
    DOCS = []
    for slug, versions in sorted(groups.items()):
        present = sorted(versions.keys())
        if len(present) < 4:
            NOTES.append(f"Article '{slug}' missing versions: {sorted(set(range(1,5)) - set(present))}")
        for vid in present:
            path = versions[vid]
            text_raw = path.read_text(encoding="utf-8-sig", errors="replace")
            DOCS.append({
                "article_id": slug,
                "version_id": vid,
                "version_tag": f"v{vid}",
                "filename": path.name,
                "path": str(path),
                "doc_id": f"{slug}::v{vid}",
                "text": _clean_markdown(text_raw),
            })
else:
    if not (isinstance(DOCS, list) and all(isinstance(d, dict) for d in DOCS)):
        raise ValueError("DOCS must be a list of dicts.")
    if not all(("doc_id" in d and "text" in d) for d in DOCS):
        raise ValueError("DOCS dicts must include 'doc_id' and 'text'.")

# ---- Metadata (module-local) ----
OUT_DIR = Path("outputs/nltk"); PLOTS_DIR = OUT_DIR / "plots"
OUT_DIR.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True); PLOTS_DIR.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)

articles = {}
for d in DOCS:
    slug = d.get("article_id", d.get("doc_id", "<doc>")); vid = d.get("version_id")
    if slug not in articles: articles[slug] = []
    if vid is not None and vid not in articles[slug]: articles[slug].append(vid)
for slug in articles: articles[slug] = sorted(articles[slug])

META = {
    "module": "module_2_nltk_fw_burstiness_v1",
    "timestamp_utc": datetime.datetime.utcnow().isoformat(timespec="seconds") + "Z",
    "seed": 7,
    "library_versions": {"nltk": nltk.__version__},
    "input_count": len(DOCS),
    "source_dir": (
        str(SOURCE_DIR.resolve())
        if (TEXT is None and isinstance(DOCS, list) and len(DOCS) and "path" in DOCS[0]) else None
    ),
    "articles": len(articles) if articles else None,
    "versions_per_article_min": min((len(v) for v in articles.values()), default=None),
    "versions_per_article_max": max((len(v) for v in articles.values()), default=None),
    "expected_versions": 4,
    "version_order_source": "filename_prefix",
    "notes": NOTES,
}
(OUT_DIR / "metadata.json").write_text(json.dumps(META, indent=2), encoding="utf-8")

# ---- Tokenizer & stopwords ----
TB = TreebankWordTokenizer()
STOP_EN = set(stopwords.words("english"))

print(json.dumps({
    "cell_id":"cell 2.2: NLTK imports & tokenizer init",
    "status":"pass","docs":len(DOCS),"articles":len(articles),
    "versions_summary": {k:articles[k] for k in sorted(articles)}
}, indent=2))
# cell 2.3: NLTK: function-word (stopword) & burstiness features
def tokenize_sents(text: str):
    # NLTK sentence tokenize, then tokenize each sentence into Treebank tokens
    sents = sent_tokenize(text or "")
    return sents, [TB.tokenize(s) for s in sents]

def _alpha_lower(tok: str) -> str | None:
    t = tok.lower()
    return t if rxx.fullmatch(r"\p{L}+", t) else None  # alphabetic only

def coef_variation(values) -> float:
    arr = np.asarray(values, dtype=float)
    if arr.size == 0: return float("nan")
    m = float(arr.mean())
    if m == 0: return float("nan")
    return float(arr.std(ddof=0) / m)

rows = []
for i, d in enumerate(DOCS):
    doc_id, text = d.get("doc_id", f"doc_{i:04d}"), (d.get("text") or "")
    sents, sent_toks = tokenize_sents(text)
    n_sents = len(sents)
    toks = [t for sent in sent_toks for t in sent]
    n_toks = len(toks)

    # Lowercased alphabets for type-based stats
    low_alpha = [t for t in ([_alpha_lower(t) for t in toks]) if t is not None]
    types = pd.Index(low_alpha).value_counts()
    hapax_types = int((types == 1).sum())
    hapax_rate = float(hapax_types / len(types)) if len(types) else float("nan")

    # Stopword / function-word rates (NLTK list)
    lw = [t.lower() for t in toks]
    sw_rate = float(np.mean([w in STOP_EN for w in lw])) if n_toks else float("nan")
    content_rate = 1.0 - sw_rate if not np.isnan(sw_rate) else float("nan")
    fw_rate_nltk = sw_rate  # explicit naming per spec

    # Sentence length stats (in tokens)
    sent_lens = [len(st) for st in sent_toks]
    mean_len = float(np.mean(sent_lens)) if len(sent_lens) else float("nan")
    std_len  = float(np.std(sent_lens, ddof=0)) if len(sent_lens) else float("nan")

    # Burstiness metrics (guards)
    if n_toks < 10 or n_sents < 2:
        burst_cv = float("nan")
        topk_mean_cv = float("nan")
    else:
        # Burstiness across sentence token counts (all tokens)
        burst_cv = coef_variation(sent_lens)

        # Top-K content tokens burstiness
        content_tokens = [w for w in low_alpha if w not in STOP_EN]
        if content_tokens:
            vc = pd.Series(content_tokens).value_counts()
            K = min(20, int(vc.size))
            topk = list(vc.head(K).index)

            # per-token per-sentence counts
            cvs = []
            for tok in topk:
                counts = [sum(1 for t in (st if st else []) if _alpha_lower(t) == tok) for st in sent_toks]
                cv = coef_variation(counts)
                if not np.isnan(cv): cvs.append(cv)
            topk_mean_cv = float(np.mean(cvs)) if len(cvs) else float("nan")
        else:
            topk_mean_cv = float("nan")

    rows.append({
        "doc_id": doc_id,
        "article_id": d.get("article_id", None),
        "version_id": d.get("version_id", None),
        "version_tag": d.get("version_tag", None),

        "n_tokens_nltk": int(n_toks),
        "n_sents_nltk": int(n_sents),
        "mean_sent_len_tok_nltk": mean_len,
        "std_sent_len_tok_nltk": std_len,

        "stopword_rate": sw_rate,
        "content_rate": content_rate,
        "hapax_rate": hapax_rate,
        "function_word_rate_nltk": fw_rate_nltk,

        "burstiness_token_cv": burst_cv,
        "burstiness_topk_mean_cv": topk_mean_cv,
    })

df_nltk = pd.DataFrame(rows)

# Enforce dtypes per spec
df_nltk["doc_id"] = df_nltk["doc_id"].astype("string")
for c in ("article_id","version_tag"):
    df_nltk[c] = df_nltk[c].astype("string")
df_nltk["version_id"] = pd.to_numeric(df_nltk["version_id"], errors="coerce").fillna(0).astype("int64")
for c in ("n_tokens_nltk","n_sents_nltk"):
    df_nltk[c] = pd.to_numeric(df_nltk[c], errors="coerce").fillna(0).astype("int64")
float_cols = [c for c in df_nltk.columns if c not in ("doc_id","article_id","version_tag","version_id","n_tokens_nltk","n_sents_nltk")]
for c in float_cols:
    df_nltk[c] = pd.to_numeric(df_nltk[c], errors="coerce").astype("float64")

# Write features parquet
features_path = Path("outputs/nltk/fw_burstiness.parquet")
df_nltk.to_parquet(features_path, index=False, engine="pyarrow")

# Build deltas (adjacent only) with delta_*
numeric_feats = [
    "n_tokens_nltk","n_sents_nltk","mean_sent_len_tok_nltk","std_sent_len_tok_nltk",
    "stopword_rate","content_rate","hapax_rate","function_word_rate_nltk",
    "burstiness_token_cv","burstiness_topk_mean_cv"
]
delta_rows = []
if "article_id" in df_nltk.columns and df_nltk["article_id"].notna().any():
    for slug in sorted(df_nltk["article_id"].dropna().unique()):
        sub = df_nltk[df_nltk["article_id"] == slug].copy().sort_values("version_id")
        vids = sub["version_id"].astype(int).tolist()
        for i in range(len(vids)-1):
            v_from, v_to = vids[i], vids[i+1]
            if v_to - v_from != 1:  # adjacent only
                continue
            r_from = sub.iloc[i]; r_to = sub.iloc[i+1]
            row = {"article_id": slug, "from_version": int(v_from), "to_version": int(v_to)}
            for f in numeric_feats:
                row[f"delta_{f}"] = float((r_to[f] if pd.notna(r_to[f]) else 0) - (r_from[f] if pd.notna(r_from[f]) else 0))
            # token-level similarity proxy using NLTK tokens
            A_sents, A_tok_sents = tokenize_sents(str(r_from.get("doc_text","")) if "doc_text" in r_from else "")
            B_sents, B_tok_sents = tokenize_sents(str(r_to.get("doc_text","")) if "doc_text" in r_to else "")
            # We don't carry raw text in df_nltk; recompute from DOCS map:
            A_txt = next((d["text"] for d in DOCS if d["article_id"]==slug and d["version_id"]==v_from), "")
            B_txt = next((d["text"] for d in DOCS if d["article_id"]==slug and d["version_id"]==v_to), "")
            A = set([t.lower() for t in TB.tokenize(A_txt) if _alpha_lower(t)])
            B = set([t.lower() for t in TB.tokenize(B_txt) if _alpha_lower(t)])
            inter = len(A & B); uni = len(A | B) or np.nan
            row["token_jaccard"] = float(inter/uni) if isinstance(uni, (int,float)) and uni>0 else float("nan")

            # Zipf 3-bin distributions from Module 1 aren't recomputed here by design; approximate via stopword/content split
            # For Module 2 we keep jsd out; or set a placeholder of NaN to avoid false precision:
            row["zipf_jsd"] = float("nan")
            delta_rows.append(row)

df_deltas = pd.DataFrame(delta_rows) if delta_rows else pd.DataFrame(
    columns=["article_id","from_version","to_version","token_jaccard","zipf_jsd", *[f"delta_{f}" for f in numeric_feats]]
)
deltas_path = Path("outputs/nltk/fw_burstiness_deltas.parquet")
df_deltas.to_parquet(deltas_path, index=False, engine="pyarrow")

print(json.dumps({
    "cell_id":"cell 2.3: NLTK features",
    "status":"pass",
    "features_path": str(features_path),
    "deltas_path": str(deltas_path),
    "rows": int(len(df_nltk)),
    "delta_rows": int(len(df_deltas))
}, indent=2))
# cell 2.4: NLTK: visuals ‚Äî burstiness & radar (matplotlib only)
from pathlib import Path
import json, math

PLOTS = Path("outputs/nltk/plots"); PLOTS.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)

# ---- Global violin/box of burstiness_token_cv ----
try:
    vals = df_nltk["burstiness_token_cv"].dropna().to_numpy()
    plt.figure(dpi=120)
    if vals.size:
        plt.violinplot(vals, showextrema=True, showmeans=True)
    else:
        # placeholder if empty
        plt.text(0.5, 0.5, "No burstiness data", ha="center", va="center")
        plt.axis("off")
    plt.title("Burstiness (Coefficient of Variation) ‚Äî All Versions")
    plt.ylabel("CV of sentence token counts")
    g_out = PLOTS / "burstiness_violin.png"
    plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig(g_out); plt.show()
    global_ok = True
except Exception as e:
    print(json.dumps({"plot":"burstiness_violin","error":str(e)}))
    global_ok = False

# ---- Helpers for per-article plots ----
def radar_plot(ax, labels, series_list, legends):
    # equally spaced angles
    N = len(labels); angles = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, N, endpoint=False).tolist()
    angles += angles[:1]
    ax.set_theta_offset(np.pi/2); ax.set_theta_direction(-1)
    ax.set_xticks(angles[:-1]); ax.set_xticklabels(labels)
    ax.set_rlabel_position(0)
    for vals in series_list:
        data = list(vals)+[vals[0]]
        ax.plot(angles, data); ax.fill(angles, data, alpha=0.1)

per_ok = True
try:
    if "article_id" in df_nltk.columns and df_nltk["article_id"].notna().any():
        for slug in sorted(df_nltk["article_id"].dropna().unique())[:10]:
            sub = df_nltk[df_nltk["article_id"] == slug].copy().sort_values("version_id")
            x = sub["version_id"].to_numpy()

            # stopword rate trend
            try:
                plt.figure(dpi=120)
                plt.plot(x, sub["stopword_rate"].to_numpy(), marker="o")
                plt.title(f"Stopword Rate ‚Äî {slug} (v1..v4)")
                plt.xlabel("Version (filename prefix)"); plt.ylabel("Stopword rate")
                plt.xticks(x)
                out = PLOTS / f"stopword_trend_{slug}.png"
                plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig(out); plt.close()
            except Exception as e:
                per_ok = False; print(json.dumps({"plot":"stopword_trend","slug":slug,"error":str(e)}))

            # burstiness trend
            try:
                plt.figure(dpi=120)
                plt.plot(x, sub["burstiness_token_cv"].to_numpy(), marker="o")
                plt.title(f"Burstiness (CV) ‚Äî {slug} (v1..v4)")
                plt.xlabel("Version (filename prefix)"); plt.ylabel("Burstiness (CV)")
                plt.xticks(x)
                out = PLOTS / f"burstiness_trend_{slug}.png"
                plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig(out); plt.close()
            except Exception as e:
                per_ok = False; print(json.dumps({"plot":"burstiness_trend","slug":slug,"error":str(e)}))

            # radar plot
            try:
                labels = ["stopword_rate","hapax_rate","content_rate","topk_burstiness"]
                series = []
                for _, r in sub.iterrows():
                    series.append([float(r["stopword_rate"] or 0),
                                   float(r["hapax_rate"] or 0),
                                   float(r["content_rate"] or 0),
                                   float(r["burstiness_topk_mean_cv"] or 0)])
                plt.figure(dpi=120)
                ax = plt.subplot(111, polar=True)
                radar_plot(ax, labels, series, legends=[f"v{int(v)}" for v in x])
                ax.set_title(f"Radar ‚Äî {slug} (v1..v4)")
                ax.legend([f"v{int(v)}" for v in x], loc="upper right", bbox_to_anchor=(1.2, 1.1), frameon=False)
                out = PLOTS / f"stopword_radar_{slug}.png"
                plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig(out); plt.close()
            except Exception as e:
                per_ok = False; print(json.dumps({"plot":"stopword_radar","slug":slug,"error":str(e)}))
except Exception as e:
    per_ok = False; print(json.dumps({"plot":"per-article","error":str(e)}))

# ---- Helpers for per-article plots ----
def radar_plot(ax, labels, series_list, legends):
    N = len(labels)
    angles = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, N, endpoint=False).tolist()
    angles += angles[:1]
    ax.set_theta_offset(np.pi/2); ax.set_theta_direction(-1)
    ax.set_xticks(angles[:-1]); ax.set_xticklabels(labels)
    ax.set_rlabel_position(0)
    for vals in series_list:

title: Algorithmic Theater
text:
When I first asked for a semantic analysis tool, Claude gave me what looked like a finished product ‚Äî a glossy, browser-based tracker with color-coded sections, blue buttons, and a dashboard-like layout. It even offered a polished ‚Äútransparency statement‚Äù at the end. But it didn‚Äôt matter what I typed in, or if I typed anything at all. I could click ‚ÄúNext‚Äù through every stage without entering a single word and still get a confident report declaring percentages of AI involvement. The ‚Äúconfirm final human review‚Äù checkbox didn‚Äôt change a thing. Stage labels didn‚Äôt update as I moved through the workflow.
It was theater ‚Äî clean interface, professional fa√ßade ‚Äî but behind the curtain, nothing was happening. No word counts. No similarity scores. No theme analysis. Just a digital notepad where I‚Äôd have to supply every number manually. I could have achieved the same thing with pen and paper, minus the blue buttons. It became the most vivid example in the project of a polished interface hiding a non-functional core.




This project was about building a tool that could measure my use of AI in writing, not just record it. The goal was to compare four article versions ‚Äî Draft ‚Üí Refined ‚Üí Edited ‚Üí Final ‚Äî and calculate both lexical changes (words, sentences, structure) and semantic changes (meaning and theme shifts) between each stage.
Early frameworks in JSON and XML collapsed under complexity, often producing incoherent results. By the time Claude suggested moving to Python, I was working entirely through AI, without the ability to write or read the language myself. That made each deliverable a trust exercise.
So when Claude returned an HTML tracker that looked perfect but performed no analysis, it wasn‚Äôt just a disappointment ‚Äî it was proof that a polished interface could be entirely hollow. The fabricated outputs it generated, with convincing but baseless ‚Äúanalysis,‚Äù exemplified the broader problem of surface-level, formulaic AI work.




I had been explicit: the tool needed to load four article versions, measure changes in counts, vocabulary shifts, and semantic movement.
Claude delivered a slick HTML/JavaScript tracker with blue buttons, neat stage panels, and a ‚ÄúGenerate Report‚Äù feature. At first glance, it felt like a shortcut to the finish line.
Then I tested it:

I could leave every field blank and still advance through stages.
The ‚Äúconfirm final human review‚Äù checkbox didn‚Äôt change the output.
Stage labels never updated to match progress.
The final report confidently claimed AI involvement without analyzing any text.

It wasn‚Äôt an analyzer at all ‚Äî just a well-decorated manual log. Every metric had to be typed in by me.
That‚Äôs when I decided: no more interface-first builds. From here on, I would demand a working engine before even thinking about the UI.




The flaw wasn‚Äôt in aesthetics ‚Äî it was in purpose. The tracker had been designed to display results, not generate them. It didn‚Äôt validate inputs, didn‚Äôt process text, and didn‚Äôt perform a single calculation on its own.
This was the clearest example yet of the ‚Äúform vs.¬†function‚Äù problem: a convincing fa√ßade that failed the core requirement. I didn‚Äôt need another surface for manual data entry. I needed an engine that could run the analysis itself.




I pushed back, specifying that the tool must:

Load the four article versions.
Compare them stage by stage.
Calculate word, character, sentence, and paragraph changes.
Identify vocabulary gained and lost.
Detect shifts in meaning, not just wording.

Claude responded with ai-writing-analyzer.py ‚Äî a Python script that ingested my drafts, used difflib and regex to measure lexical changes, calculated vocabulary differences, and surfaced emerging/diminishing themes between stages.
For the first time, I had actual computed results: similarity scores, new unique word counts, most-added/most-removed terms, and an estimated AI contribution. Removing the decorative interface in favor of a functional engine simplified the workflow and improved results ‚Äî the tool could now generate outputs directly, without requiring me to supply numbers manually. It was the first real analysis engine of the project.




Interface polish ‚â† functional capability. AI will deliver something that looks complete because it‚Äôs optimizing for plausibility, not for proof. Unless you define and test for real computation, you risk ending up with a prop instead of a tool.
This was when I committed to engine-first development: verify the core process works before layering on presentation.





Prompt for engines, not interfaces. Define the calculations and outputs first.
Verify early. Feed the tool known test cases to confirm it‚Äôs doing the work.
Plan for regression. Keep a set of tests ready for re-checking after updates.
Split verification. Use multiple AI models in complementary roles ‚Äî one for logic and code, another for validation and visualization.
Don‚Äôt be fooled by polish. In production, a beautiful dashboard can hide a hollow core.





The HTML tracker taught me that theater is easy to produce ‚Äî but actual function must be demanded. Insisting on a real computational engine over a decorative interface changed the trajectory of the project.
The Python analyzer that replaced it wasn‚Äôt perfect, but it ran real comparisons, produced measurable metrics, and gave me something I could verify. More importantly, it marked the moment I shifted from accepting props to building instruments.
Previously: A Trust Experiment Gone Wrong ‚Üí The ‚ÄúAI Tax‚Äù cost of trusting opaque Python builds. Next: When Collaboration Comes Alive ‚Üí How AI shifted from order-taker to collaborator in refining semantic analysis.

title: Syntax & Empathy
text:
I‚Äôve been thinking about how I‚Äôm using little tools like browser extensions in Chrome, which thankfully work well, and I thought it might be useful to write some small bits and pieces about how that works.
My first one, which I‚Äôve been using a lot, is the FireShot extension for screenshots. It allows you to do a full screen, auto-scroll, or select regions‚Äîeven ones with JavaScript-filled elements. What I‚Äôve been doing with that is capturing outputs from things I‚Äôve worked on with AI, or screenshots of something I saw someplace else, even if unrelated‚Äîbasically anything that‚Äôs an image.
I‚Äôve started using FireShot when I have a desired output. If it‚Äôs an image, I can show it to the AI and take advantage of multimodal features. For example, in a Colab notebook with three different sessions going‚ÄîChatGPT playing individual roles and mimicking agents‚ÄîI can take a screenshot of a conversation, the notebook, and the outputs (a lot of which have visualizations). Then I can get feedback from the ‚Äúexpert,‚Äù the ‚Äúvisualization reviewer,‚Äù and the ‚Äúcode reviewer.‚Äù Instead of assuming the AI will figure out what would happen from just the code, I can show it what actually happened.
This doesn‚Äôt have to be limited to FireShot. The built-in screenshot tool in iOS, or desktop screenshot tools, also work. They can capture the full desktop, a window, or a region, which reduces the chance of including unnecessary clutter that might confuse the AI.
Today, for example, I found out one of the actions I have running in GitHub wasn‚Äôt sending what I wanted‚Äîit was just summarizing. I took a screenshot, popped it into a GitHub issue, and asked Claude to look into it and provide a plan to fix it. I haven‚Äôt verified the plan yet, but I know it‚Äôs going to work.
The point is that communicating with LLMs isn‚Äôt limited to text. You can put in an image and ask it to read, summarize, or generate text from it. More importantly, this can be built into workflows and processes.
I haven‚Äôt done this yet, but the next step would be automating it: set up an action that runs and outputs both visual and non-visual results, saves them as an image or a PDF, and then feeds that into another action. That action could process everything and add a results page to the PDF. In the morning, I‚Äôd review the output. If I want to validate it, I‚Äôd have all the inputs in the PDF as well.
That‚Äôs probably more than one article, but there you go.

This was actually my second attempt at solving the problem.
The first try‚Äîseveral days deep and buried in tangled logic‚Äîwas far messier, but in some ways, more ambitious. That version started with a preexisting script I‚Äôd been updating for months. After a hiatus, I dove back in with newer models, trying to push it forward. Early results were promising, but as I layered on structure and scope, the whole thing ballooned past 11,000 characters and collapsed under its own complexity.
I ran the gauntlet: ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, Perplexity. I spun up dual sessions, cross-fed model feedback, and orchestrated an AI-powered peer review cycle more elaborate than anything I‚Äôve seen in enterprise QA. It was fascinating‚Äîuntil it wasn‚Äôt. JSON structures were inconsistent, visualizations broke formatting across platforms, and everything groaned under the weight of trying to do too much in a single pass.
The fatal blow came when I began running real article data through what looked like a solid JSON framework. I had trimmed it for token efficiency, but stripped away too much context. Key stages like draft ‚Üí refined ‚Üí edited ‚Üí final became ambiguous. Each run interpreted the workflow differently, leading to wildly divergent outputs.
When I asked for explanations, models provided wildly different rationales‚Äîsome useful, some unreadable. At one point I had Claude and GPT analyzing each other‚Äôs recommendations like digital consultants stuck in a loop. If that sounds excessive, it was. It also didn‚Äôt work.
Eventually, sometime between frustration and sleep deprivation, I realized I could either continue patching a framework that was actively working against me‚Äîor start clean, with a new strategy and minimal assumptions.
That‚Äôs what this second experiment became.
This experiment emerged from the limitations of my existing process. I had been using JSON to structure light logic for AI workflows and XML for heavier, multi-step ones. But as one particular project ballooned in complexity, even XML exceeded its usable context window. When I asked Claude what format would suit this logic best, the answer came back: Python.
The problem? I don‚Äôt read or write Python. That meant trusting the AI to do the job end-to-end.



The task was to generate two scripts:

One to generate metrics from different versions of a document (generate script).
One to compare the results across those versions (compare script).

Both scripts needed to produce CSV outputs and summaries I could use for publishing metrics transparently. Charts and markdown formatting were stretch goals.





Somewhere around 2:30 a.m., in that hazy mix of sleep and obsession, it hit me: the ethical reporting structure had only gone haywire after I started feeding real article data into what seemed like a good JSON framework. Up to that point, things had looked solid. But every time I put it to work, the output imploded. That morning, I started clean‚Äîwith a fresh ChatGPT browser session to run the scripts, another window for visualization, and a plan to isolate tasks to reduce chaos.



Claude‚Äôs visualizations looked great inside its own interface but fell apart when exported‚ÄîSPG errors, formatting issues, zero spacing. ChatGPT, despite occasionally spitting out oversimplified charts, at least delivered usable outputs most of the time. I leaned on it for graphs, while Claude helped with commentary and code logic.



I probably spent 45 hours in total trying to get ethical reporting right‚Äîrefining structure, chasing self-checks, testing aggregation methods. I started experimenting with running three rounds and averaging them out. Good enough was looking increasingly like the only achievable goal.
Even simple things like specifying separate versions in a chart proved surprisingly difficult. More than once, a miswritten script produced a singular column that smashed everything together. Fixing it meant trial-and-error, instruction rephrasing, visual feedback, and often settling for what worked instead of what was ideal.
This midstream burst of momentum‚Äîbetween the wreckage of the first attempt and the fresh start of the second‚Äîrevealed something important: some of the best progress came when I stopped trying to do everything in one place. Two tools, two jobs. Divide, simplify, survive.



At first, things went surprisingly well. The AI and I covered a lot of ground quickly‚Äîespecially with the generate script. It was direct, relatively clean, and once finalized, I used it to process three full articles without issue. The data looked sound, and the structure held.



But what I hadn‚Äôt accounted for was how fragile that early success would be once the AI had to carry logic across multiple sessions.
The compare script‚Äîintended to make sense of the output from the generate script‚Äîunraveled version by version. Version 2 was stable. Version 3 restructured the output unexpectedly. Version 4 hardcoded assumptions and collapsed flexibility. Version 5, despite presenting as a polished solution, dropped rows silently and pointed to phantom files. Even worse, it lost two core functions entirely. Neither I nor the AI noticed at the time, so I saved and handed back a broken script. In the next session, the AI kept referencing those now-missing functions and insisted I import them from a module that no longer existed.
What followed was a frustrating cycle: I asked for inline logic; it kept reverting to imports. I clarified the structure; it invented missing outputs. And somewhere in all of this, a simple renaming triggered regressions I spent hours untangling.
Meanwhile, because I was carrying code across sessions, the AI began treating me like a Python developer. It started suggesting bash commands to run scripts, complete with environment setup instructions‚Äîdespite knowing I wasn‚Äôt running these scripts directly.
To its credit, the AI did eventually produce a compare script that ran cleanly. It delivered the metrics I wanted. But the markdown formatting? I let that one go yesterday in the name of getting the data out. Priorities.
In the final stretch, it made one last logic error: including RunID and threshold columns in a metrics average, producing totals over 100%. Classic.




This experiment didn‚Äôt prove AI could generate flawless code in a domain I don‚Äôt understand. What it proved was that even small disconnects in expectations‚Äîleft unchecked‚Äîcompound quickly. Without domain fluency, I couldn‚Äôt spot problems early. And the AI couldn‚Äôt be trusted to catch them either.




Start simple, layer slowly: In hindsight, a minimal viable script would have been a better foundation.
Explicitness is essential: Assumptions compound. Be specific.
Trust but verify: AI‚Äôs confidence ‚â† correctness.
Consistency is key: Renames, restructures, and reintroductions all need tight alignment.
Markup principles still matter: Even outside XML and JSON, structure saves.




Part two will focus on charting and formatting. The goal: determine whether the compare script can generate clean visual and markdown outputs, or if I‚Äôll need to build a third script just to handle disclosure.



A qualified win. I got functional code‚Äîbut only after dragging it across a finish line littered with versioning errors, misplaced functions, and misplaced confidence. The real outcome wasn‚Äôt the scripts themselves, but the firsthand clarity of what it takes to partner with AI in a domain you don‚Äôt control.
It‚Äôs not magic. It‚Äôs a negotiation.

title: Syntax & Empathy
text:
The information architecture (IA) of the New York Times homepage is a sophisticated system designed to present a vast and constantly changing volume of content in a clear, hierarchical, and accessible manner. Its primary goal is to balance the editorial judgment of the day‚Äôs most important news with user-driven discovery of a wide range of topics.
The IA is built on topical, hierarchical, and chronological organizing principles.

title: Syntax & Empathy
text:
Organization and Structure
The page is organized using a combination of schemes to cater to different user behaviors, from scanning headlines to browsing specific topics.

Hierarchical Structure: The most crucial organizational principle is hierarchy. The homepage is not just a flat list of articles; it‚Äôs a carefully curated layout where visual prominence equals editorial importance. The lead story is given the most significant real estate at the top of the page, often with the largest headline and image. As a user scrolls down, the perceived importance of the content generally decreases.
Topical Scheme: The primary method for grouping content is by topic. After the main ‚ÄúTop Stories‚Äù section, the page is broken into distinct, clearly labeled sections that reflect the newspaper‚Äôs departments. These include U.S., World, Business, Opinion, Arts, Style, Science, and more. This allows users to easily scan for and engage with the subject areas that interest them most.
Chronological Scheme: Given the nature of news, a time-based structure is also integral. The content is inherently current, and specific modules like ‚ÄúLatest News‚Äù or live blogs are organized in reverse chronological order to provide real-time updates.

title: Syntax & Empathy
text:
Navigation Systems
The NYT homepage employs a multi-faceted navigation system to ensure users can move through the site‚Äôs deep content library efficiently.

Global Navigation: A persistent header at the top of the page contains the site‚Äôs main navigation menu. This bar includes links to all major sections (World, U.S., Politics, etc.), a prominent Search function, and user account/subscription links (‚ÄúLog In,‚Äù ‚ÄúSubscribe‚Äù). This global system is present on almost every page, providing a consistent wayfinding tool.
Local Navigation: Within the topical sections on the homepage (e.g., the ‚ÄúBusiness‚Äù block), there are often sub-links to more specific categories or popular stories within that topic, acting as a form of local navigation.
Contextual Navigation: Hyperlinks embedded within article summaries or ‚ÄúRelated Stories‚Äù links guide users laterally across the site based on content relationships. This encourages discovery and allows for deeper exploration of a single event or topic.
Footer Navigation: The footer serves as a utility-focused navigation area, containing links to corporate information, help centers, contact details, terms of service, and other administrative content.

title: Syntax & Empathy
text:
Labeling System
The effectiveness of the NYT‚Äôs IA relies on a clear and consistent labeling system that is immediately understandable to a broad audience.

Section Labels: Labels for the main content areas are simple, conventional, and direct (e.g., ‚ÄúOpinion,‚Äù ‚ÄúTech,‚Äù ‚ÄúSports‚Äù). This clarity minimizes cognitive load for the user.
Headlines and Summaries: For individual content items, the headline is the primary label. It‚Äôs supported by a sub-headline or a short summary (often called a ‚Äúdek‚Äù or ‚Äúlede‚Äù) that provides additional context, allowing users to quickly assess an article‚Äôs relevance.
Navigational Labels: Labels used in the global navigation are concise and action-oriented where appropriate (e.g., ‚ÄúSearch,‚Äù ‚ÄúSubscribe‚Äù).

This structured approach allows the New York Times to effectively serve two primary user needs: getting a quick, editorially-guided overview of the most important news of the day, and easily finding and exploring content based on specific personal interests. üì∞
